hero.description: A 1.500 km cycling trip from Munich to Monaco, passing the massive glaciers of the Alps and crossing its most spectacular cols. A cycling adventure to enjoy the beauty of the Alps and face the harsh reality of climate change, while raising money to support CO<sub>2</sub> removal projects.

launch.announcement: The goal, the route and how you can participate will be announced on Friday March 21st live from the World Glacier Day in Paris.
launch.join: You can join the online launch event at 9.00 AM here.

why.p1: Glaciers are essential to life on Earth. Billions of people - whether in mountainous regions or larger cities - depend on them for freshwater supply and food production. Glaciers are our natural water reservoirs.
why.p2: However, glaciers are retreating at an alarming rate due to climate change. This threatens ecosystems, water resources, and human communities. Melting glaciers contribute significantly to sea-level rise, posing risks to coastal communities and causing saltwater intrusion into freshwater supplies.
why.p3: The less ice there is, the less water there is for human use, whether it's for drinking, hydroelectric generation, or irrigation. To keep our planet livable, we need to protect our glaciers and halt climate change.

sustainability.message: We have to stop treating our atmosphere as a sewer and start to remove CO<sub>2</sub> to preserve our glaciers and secure a sustainable future for all.

map.source: The glaciers in the alps have lost more than half their volume since this map was drawn in the 1930's.

support.description:
The Goodbye Glacier Ride is initiated to show the bitter reality of climate change, but more important: to ignite action to do something about it.

This is where you come in! You can support the riders by ordering one or more of the limited edition postcards. The postcard will be sent from the location with a personal note.

While the riders sweat, your contribution is used to remove CO2 from the atmosphere. The revenue is used to fund Carbon Dioxide Removal projects that increase local income, improves soil quality and enables climate finance: a Triple Win.
support.register: Do you want to ride (a part of) the Goodbye Glacier Ride yourself and start your own Carbon-Sinking campaign? You can register here.

info.un: To highlight the importance of glaciers, the United Nations has designated 2025 as the International Year of Glaciers' Preservation.
info.initiative: The Goodbye Glacier Ride is an initiative of Cycling 4 Climate. A not for profit but for impact foundation from The Netherlands.

faq.question1: What is the Goodbye Glacier ride?
faq.answer1: The Goodbye Glacier ride is an individual cycling adventure to raise awareness on climate disruption. Participants fundraise carbon removal: they invite friends, family, etc to start removing CO<sub>2</sub> from the atmosphere via their fundraising campaign.
faq.answer2: Your donation is used to fund a Carbon Removal from the Carboneers. Each euro removes 6.67 kg of CO<sub>2</sub> from the atmosphere. To remove and store 1000 kg (= 1 ton) of CO<sub>2</sub> costs €150. If you donate via a postcard, €5 is used for printing and porto costs, the rest is 100% used to remove CO<sub>2</sub> from the atmosphere
faq.question3: Can I also ride a part of the Goodbye Glacier ride?
faq.answer3: Yes you can. Ideally you pass at least the Morteratsch, Rhône and Aletsch glaciers, and visit the Mer de Glace in Chamonix.
faq.question4: What do I need to ride the Goodbye Glacier ride?
faq.answer4:
A good condition!
And the commitment to sink at least 100 ton’s of CO2. We expect from participants that they'll find 100 people that will sink one ton of CO2 (or 200 people to sink 500 kg each).
Since it costs €150 to remove one ton of CO2, the target fundraising amount is €15.000.
faq.question5: What does it cost to ride the Goodbye Glacier ride?
faq.answer5: Registration fee for the GGR is € 25. Therefore you’ll get the GPX-file, the day planning and a personal fundraising page on the website. You’ll also receive the digital print files of the postcards you can send to your supporters and you’ll be included in the list of Goodbye Glacier Riders. </br>The Goodbye Glacier cycling jersey is optional and can be purchased in the webshop of Cycling 4 Climate (make sure you select the right side).
faq.answer6:
A process where CO2 from the atmosphere is captured and stored for 1000 of years. Humanity is currently on a trajectory to overshoot the 1,5C global temperature increase target. To bring the earth system back into a stable, liveable state, we need to remove excess CO2 from the atmosphere.

How does this work?
Excess biowasted is transformed into biochar. Biochar is a kind of charcoal, that is very stable. The biochar is applied to the soil, where it improves its quality and the carbon is stored for millenia. There is a triple advantage: smallholder farmers gain extra income while their soils improve and become more resilient to climate change.
